comments:
Build: 20020611
JDK: IBM JDK 1.3.1 - 20020403

I get an error every time I try to open a .doc 
file.

Follow these steps:

1. New workspace
2. New simple project "Docs".
3. Drag & 
drop CALLBACK.DOC from the desktop into Docs. (see attachment)
4. Double click CALLBACK.DOC <- 
Error occurs
5. Try to exit Eclipse, no can do!  Terminate Eclipse with a Ctrl-C.
6. Relaunch 
Eclipse... CALLBACK.DOC (& the error) returns (run screaming to the hills, AIIEEE!)

The 
following things happen at step 5:
1. CALLBACK.DOC is opened in WordPad.
2. CALLBACK.DOC is 
also opened in a blank editor in Eclipse.
3. The Eclipse editor for CALLBACK.DOC is marked 
dirty.  Revert is greyed out in the File menu, and every attempt to close CALLBACK.DOC fails, i.e. 
when you click the Editor X you get prompted to save, no matter what answer you give, the file 
remains open.  This is especially nasty because it means you can't close Eclipse.  I had to 
terminate the process with a Ctrl-C in the Java console.
4. The following appears in the 
log:

As I see it, there are 5 parts to 
this bug:
1. Can't open .doc files without an error
2. Error handling near OLE needs to guard 
against two editors (both internal & external)
3. No way to close the dirty editor that 
appears
4. Loose "save file" handling makes clean shutdown impossible
5. Restore code 
shouldn't restore faulty editors (particularly dirty ones!)

Created an attachment (id=1360)
Callback.zip - a zip of CALLBACK.DOC
I believe any .doc file will exhibit this behaviour.

Important update:

If your machine has Office installed, this test will not fail!

The second NPE is similar.  
OleClientSite.onPaint also does not check for null from getProgramID().

The last two NPEs appear to be the same as the previous one.
My guess is that OleClientSite.access$2(OleClientSite.java:819) is the access 
method for onPaint.

Not clear why you get an error closing the file, but the save failure is 
probably due to OLEEditor.saveFile also calling getClientID() and not checking 
the result for null.

Also noticed that OleEditor.usesStorageFiles does:
(progID.startsWith("Word.", 0)
|| progID.startsWith("MSGraph", 0) 
|| progID.startsWith("PowerPoint", 0)
|| progID.startsWith("Excel", 0)))

Why does Word have a '.' but not the others?

Might make more sense to change OLEClientSite.getProgramID() to return "" for 
the error case instead of null.

Released null checks in OleEditor.usesStorageFiles and oleActivate.

SWT needs to fix up OleClientSite.doPaint.

Should also figure out what caused getProgramID() to return null in the first 
place.

Jed, could you please try again in today's build?
I wasn't actually able to try it without Word installed.

I cannot replicate this in the current build as I beleive that the file 
mappings on Jeds machine are different from mine. Jed do you have WordPad set 
up as the editor for doc files rather than Word? I think this might be why this 
case is different for you.

WordPad is not an OLE control so anything with the extension .doc should open 
using Word.

The problem with the dirty OLE editors is a known problem - see Bug 2486. OLE 
does not give any feedbackas to dirty state so they are currently always shown 
as dirty as we cannot be sure.
Replicated on Win XP without Office installed.

The problem is due to Bug 20007 which is a problem with the program ID of 
WordPad - OLE returns a value but the OleClientSite created by it returns null.

As we are so close to R3 if there is not a suitable fix for the SWT issue 
before the freeze we should explictly prevent the creation of embedded WordPad 
editors by testing for the them in ComponentSupport.testForOleEditor.

Tod, See http://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=19962, Eclipse should not force 
Word to open if I have set WordPad as my system editor for .doc files.

When I first encountered 
this bug I didn't have Office installed on this machine (I had just rebuilt it).  But now I do, so I see 
http://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=19962 instead of this bug.  We have a machine 
in the lab that doesn't have Office installed, I will try the latest build on that machine.

This is not fixed in the current build. We are awaiting a response from SWT.

Please note that your windows mappings do not affect OLE - the call to OLE to 
find a program id is independant of that.

Fixed in F3 (build 2)

The file created in Word contains in it the CLSID for Word.  OleCreateFromFile 
looks in the file to determine what CLSID to use when opening the file.  It 
finds Word but Word is not installed.

The fix is to check before hand to see what CLSID it will use (using 
GetClassFile) and then make sure this CLSID is installed in the current 
system.  If the CLSID is not installed, throw an exception.  This exception 
results in a message indicating the editor could not be created.
